Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Millimeter Wave Channel Measurements and Modeling for 5G Wireless Communications

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Today's mobile communications technology will soon become obsolete in the face of increasing demand for broadband data and wireless access. Since the advent of cellular and WiFi wireless technologies, wireless communications have used relatively narrowband radio channels, with relatively low ultra-high frequencies (UHF), and unsophisticated antennas. This project offers to provide fundamental knowledge about the radio channels in a much higher frequency range, where orders of magnitude more data capacity could be delivered to cellphones of the future.

The tremendous pending demand for wireless capacity is causing regulators around the world to consider opening up new mobile spectrum in the millimeter wave (mm-wave) frequency bands. To date, little is known about the small-scale behavior of mm-Wave radio channels, yet academia and industry require small-scale channel models to create new wireless system architectures and air interface standards that will use directional antennas for the first time. In this project, comprehensive 28 GHz small-scale propagation measurements in an urban setting (Brooklyn, NY) shall uncover key small scale multipath and signal properties that are currently not known or understood. The data will allow for the development of analytical and statistical channel models that are based on directional antennas. Such measurements and models are critical for the proper engineering analysis and design of future mm-wave physical layer and link layer protocols by both academia and industry, and the knowledge from this project could also lead to simulation and emulation products for fifth generation (5G) wireless product development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This EAGER project provided fundamental knowledge of future millimeter wave (mmWave) radio channels, and how they behave and can be exploited by the use of highly directional antennas. Three major contributions of the research in this project include: (1) A comprehensive measurement campaign and channel statistics for multiple base stations in an urban microcellular network along the NYU Brooklyn campus, using highly directional antennas; (2) Development and improvement of an open source software package called NYUSIM, used by 8,000 engineers to recreate realistic mmWave channels at a wide range of frequencies, bandwidths, and antenna patterns, and (3) Design and development of a new protocol and methodology for wireless devices to find other wireless devices using highly directional antennas. 

This project also provided funding for development of new graduate students to learn best practices from very senior Ph.D. students who will soon be graduating, andprovided support for NYU WIRELESS graduate students to participate in the NIST 5G Channel Alliance project that is creating best practices for measuring and modeling wireless channels across academia and industry.

The project resulted in vast improvements in the popular open-source NYUSIM channel simulation software, including support for versions up to NYUSIM 1.5, and provided support for new measurements and models by NYU thave have led to improved channel models for urban and rural mmWave channels that are more accurate than some of the recently-adopted industry standards in 3GPP and ITU WG5/D.
